answers.answer: Listen to your fiance.  You are not the problem.  On the other hand, you can be a help for improving his general health, if you can get him to exercise and eat right to deal with his obesity problem, for instance, as approved by his doctor.  As far as the ED issue here, you have to decide if you are willing to live with a man that may never be able to achieve an erection.  Hopefully, as his general health improves and with the help of a urologist, his situation would improve in time.  However, you both would have to acknowledge that improvement would be difficult at best, given what he has done so far.

question: I have been with my fiance for 16 months.  Because of obesity, diabetes, and a surgery 3 years ago he is unable to get or maintain an erection.  I am looking for resources for myself to help cope with my insecurities that I am the root of the problem and that he will meet someone that "turns him on" and leave me.  He has tried all the Rx's available and nothing helps.  We have been in a committed relationship for a very long time with no penetration.He has reassured me that it is all medical..that I am the one who turns him on...but he cant get an erection..at all...even with RX's.  I have something telling me that I am not "the one" and that some one else will come along and be the woman that he needs.  He reassures on a constant basis that I am his one and only and that he cant an erection at all..for anyone.Where should I get help for myself and my insecurities?I need help.
title: Partner has had ED throughout our entire relationship
